story.storykicker: Scientists decode colour changing pattern of Heliconius butterflies.
story.storybody:
Scientists at the University of Sheffield in UK have made a groundbreaking stride in the field of animal science.

The British scientists have identified the gene responsible for developing the colour patterns of a butterfly.Their work was published in Nature on June 1.

Here are some key points to remember:

  • Scientists found out that a gene called Cortex controls some of the major differences in butterfly warning colour patterns
  • They chose Heliconius, a common species of butterfly, which is available in most parts of the world
  • They studied a specific breed of Heliconis butterflies also known as 'passion-vine butterfly'
  • The passion vine can be found in the rainforests of South America
  • The researchers also pointed out that the purpose behind the butterfly's colour pattern was to ward off predators
  • The striking colours indicate that the butterflies are toxic
  • Predators such as birds, spiders and others follow and avoid a certain colour pattern of a butterfly within a specific area
  • The colour patterns change according to the ideas developed by predators
  • This is why butterflies have different colour patterns across regions
  • The study shows that the Cortex gene controls wing pattern variation in three different species of the Heliconius
  • Two of these species imitate each other by having almost identical colour patterns where they are found together, even though having little resemblance among each other. The third species has a different colour pattern, as it copies different species of butterflies.
